title: Finds potential security problems in AddAccessAllowedAce calls

title: Finds potential security problems in access calls
description: This usually indicates a security flaw.  If an attacker can change anything along the path between the call to access() and the file's actual use (e.g., by moving files), the attacker can exploit the race condition (CWE-362/CWE-367!)

title: Finds potential security problems in atoi calls
description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range (CWE-190)

title: Finds potential security problems in atol calls
description: Unless checked, the resulting number can exceed the expected range (CWE-190)

description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in char calls
description: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues (CWE-119!/CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in chgrp calls
description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)

title: Finds potential security problems in chmod calls
description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)

title: Finds potential security problems in chown calls
description: This accepts filename arguments; if an attacker can move those files, a race condition results. (CWE-362)

title: Finds potential security problems in chroot calls
description: chroot can be very helpful, but is hard to use correctly (CWE-250, CWE-22)

title: Finds potential security problems in crypt calls
description: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment (CWE-327)

title: Finds potential security problems in crypt_r calls
description: The crypt functions use a poor one-way hashing algorithm; since they only accept passwords of 8 characters or fewer and only a two-byte salt, they are excessively vulnerable to dictionary attacks given today's faster computing equipment (CWE-327)

title: Finds potential security problems in curl_getenv calls
description: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once (CWE-807, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in cuserid calls
description: Exactly what cuserid() does is poorly defined (e.g., some systems use the effective uid, like Linux, while others like System V use the real uid). Thus, you can't trust what it does. It's certainly not portable (The cuserid function was included in the 1988 version of POSIX, but removed from the 1990 version).  Also, if passed a non-null parameter, there's a risk of a buffer overflow if the passed-in buffer is not at least L_cuserid characters long (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in drand48 calls
description: This function is not sufficiently random for security-related functions such as key and nonce creation (CWE-327)

title: Finds potential security problems in equal calls
description: Function does not check the second iterator for over-read conditions (CWE-126)

title: Finds potential security problems in erand48 calls
description: This function is not sufficiently random for security-related functions such as key and nonce creation (CWE-327)

description: Check buffer boundaries if used in a loop including recursive loops (CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getchar calls
description: Check buffer boundaries if used in a loop including recursive loops (CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getenv calls
description: Environment variables are untrustable input if they can be set by an attacker.  They can have any content and length, and the same variable can be set more than once (CWE-807, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getlogin calls
description: It's often easy to fool getlogin.  Sometimes it does not work at all, because some program messed up the utmp file.  Often, it gives only the first 8 characters of the login name. The user currently logged in on the controlling tty of our program need not be the user who started it.  Avoid getlogin() for security-related purposes (CWE-807)

title: Finds potential security problems in getopt calls
description: Some older implementations do not protect against internal buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getopt_long calls
description: Some older implementations do not protect against internal buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getpass calls
description: This function is obsolete and not portable. It was in SUSv2 but removed by POSIX.2.  What it does exactly varies considerably between systems, particularly in where its prompt is displayed and where it gets its data (e.g., /dev/tty, stdin, stderr, etc.). In addition, some implementations overflow buffers. (CWE-676, CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getpw calls
description: This function is dangerous; it may overflow the provided buffer. It extracts data from a 'protected' area, but most systems have many commands to let users modify the protected area, and it's not always clear what their limits are.  Best to avoid using this function altogether (CWE-676, CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in gets calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in getwd calls
description: This does not protect against buffer overflows by itself, so use with caution (CWE-120, CWE-20)

title: Finds potential security problems in gsignal calls
description: These functions are considered obsolete on most systems, and very non-portable (Linux-based systems handle them radically different, basically if gsignal/ssignal were the same as raise/signal respectively, while System V considers them a separate set and obsolete) (CWE-676)

title: Finds potential security problems in is_permutation calls
description: Function does not check the second iterator for over-read conditions (CWE-126)

title: Finds potential security problems in memalign calls
description: On some systems (though not Linux-based systems) an attempt to free() results from memalign() may fail. This may, on a few systems, be exploitable.  Also note that memalign() may not check that the boundary parameter is correct (CWE-676)

title: Finds potential security problems in memcpy calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in mismatch calls
description: Function does not check the second iterator for over-read conditions (CWE-126)

title: Finds potential security problems in mkstemp calls
description: Potential for temporary file vulnerability in some circumstances.  Some older Unix-like systems create temp files with permission to write by all by default, so be sure to set the umask to override this. Also, some older Unix systems might fail to use O_EXCL when opening the file, so make sure that O_EXCL is used by the library (CWE-377)

title: Finds potential security problems in mktemp calls
description: Temporary file race condition (CWE-377)

description: Subject to buffer overflow if buffer is not as big as claimed (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strcpy calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strcpyA calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strcpyW calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strcpynA calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in streadd calls
description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strecpy calls
description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strfry calls
description: This function is not sufficiently random for security-related functions such as key and nonce creation (CWE-327)

title: Finds potential security problems in strlen calls
description: Does not handle strings that are not \0-terminated; if given one it may perform an over-read (it could cause a crash if unprotected) (CWE-126)

title: Finds potential security problems in strncat calls
description: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned] (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strncpy calls
description: Easily used incorrectly; doesn't always \0-terminate or check for invalid pointers [MS-banned] (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in strtrns calls
description: This function does not protect against buffer overflows (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in swprintf calls
description: Does not check for buffer overflows (CWE-120)

title: Finds potential security problems in syslog calls
description: If syslog's format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited (CWE-134)

title: Finds potential security problems in system calls
description: This causes a new program to execute and is difficult to use safely (CWE-78)

title: Finds potential security problems in tempnam calls
description: Temporary file race condition (CWE-377)

title: Finds potential security problems in tmpfile calls
description: Function tmpfile() has a security flaw on some systems (e.g., older System V systems) (CWE-377)

title: Finds potential security problems in tmpnam calls
description: Temporary file race condition (CWE-377)

title: Finds potential security problems in ulimit calls
description: This C routine is considered obsolete (as opposed to the shell command by the same name, which is NOT obsolete) (CWE-676)

title: Finds potential security problems in umask calls
description: Ensure that umask is given most restrictive possible setting (e.g., 066 or 077) (CWE-732)

title: Finds potential security problems in usleep calls
description: This C routine is considered obsolete (as opposed to the shell command by the same name).   The interaction of this function with SIGALRM and other timer functions such as sleep(), alarm(), setitimer(), and nanosleep() is unspecified (CWE-676)

title: Finds potential security problems in vfork calls
description: On some old systems, vfork() permits race conditions, and it's very difficult to use correctly (CWE-362)

title: Finds potential security problems in vfprintf calls
description: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited (CWE-134)

title: Finds potential security problems in vfscanf calls
